author: Staff Reporter
text:
Working women need to spend just nine minutes of quality time with their children per day to make the kids feel loved. “Women should spend minimum of three minutes each when children wake up, when they come back from school and before they go to bed,” said R. M. Anjana, Joint Managing Director, Dr Mohan’s Diabetes Specialities Centre, and Vice President of Madras Diabetes Research Foundation while talking at the Women Managers Convention 2016 organised by the Madras Management Association . She also said that women were not created to do what men can do. They were created to do what men can’t do.

Raghu Raman, Group President Risk, Security and New Ventures, Reliance Industries Ltd, said, “India should take the lead in empowering women. If you look at history we have produced more women leaders. They have to be financially and physically independent. When life punches you on your stomach you must have the ability to flip around and stand on your feet.”

Over 800 women delegates from various walks of life participated in this fourteenth edition of this convention. The conference also highlighted the importance of women in leadership roles and how their roles can be fostered, promoted and secured for the next generation.

India’s first female racing champion, Alisha Abdullah, spoke about the challenges she faced when she ventured into racing, a field that was dominated by men. N. Priya Ravichandran, Deputy Director (HQ), Tamil Nadu Fire and Rescue Services, motivated the women at the event to take up successful and challenging roles.
title: ‘India must lead in empowering women’
